para.$: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are considered rare diseases, and there have not been any well-controlled clinical trials or epidemiological studies to determine the exact prevalence and incidence of these conditions. The incidence of SJS is estimated at 1 to 6 cases/million person-years, and 0.4 to 1.2 cases/million person-years for TEN, in all races and ages and both sexes.

citation.$: Roujeau JC, Kelly JP, Naldi L, et al. Medication use and the risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis. N Engl J Med. 1995;333:1600-1608.

para.$: One case-control study determined that, of the medicines that precipitate SJS and TEN, the antibacterial sulfonamides had an excess risk of 4.5 cases/million exposed people per week.

citation.$: Roujeau JC, Kelly JP, Naldi L, et al. Medication use and the risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis. N Engl J Med. 1995;333:1600-1608.

para.$: The incidence and prevalence is increased in specific sub-populations that are exposed to particular drugs, such as anticonvulsants in patients with seizures and anti-HIV medicines in HIV-positive individuals, compared with the population not taking those medicines. HIV-positive patients have a combined incidence of SJS and TEN of 1/1000 person-years.

citation.$: Coopman SA, Johnson RA, Platt R, et al. Cutaneous disease and drug reactions in HIV infection. N Engl J Med. 1993;328:1670-1674.

Mittmann N, Knowles SR, Koo M, et al. Incidence of toxic epidermal necrolysis and Stevens-Johnson Syndrome in an HIV cohort: an observational, retrospective case series study. Am J Clin Dermatol. 2012;13:49-54.

para.$: One review found that risk estimates based on the number of prescriptions or daily doses ranged from 1 to 10/10,000 new users for carbamazepine, lamotrigine, phenobarbital, and phenytoin, and were lower for valproic acid.

citation.$: Mockenhaupt M, Messenheimer J, Tennis P, et al. Risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis in new users of antiepileptics. Neurology. 2005;64:1134-1138.
Calabrese JR, Sullivan JR, Bowden CL, et al. Rash in multicenter trials of lamotrigine in mood disorders: clinical relevance and management. J Clin Psychiatry. 2002;63:1012-1019.

para.$: Other risk factors for developing SJS/TEN are radiotherapy, collagen vascular disease, transplantation, and herpes infection.

citation.$: Roujeau JC, Kelly JP, Naldi L, et al. Medication use and the risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis. N Engl J Med. 1995;333:1600-1608.

para.$: Pharmacogenomic studies indicate that ethnicity and HLA types may predispose patients to adverse drug reactions.

para.$: HLA-B*1502 allele has a strong association with carbamazepine-induced SJS and TEN in the Han Chinese population; in the US, the FDA recommends testing all Asian people prior to prescribing this medication.

citation.$: Chang CC, Too CL, Murad S, et al. Association of HLA-B*1502 allele with carbamazepine-induced toxic epidermal necrolysis and Stevens-Johnson syndrome in the multi-ethnic Malaysian population. Int J Dermatol. 2011;50:221-224.

para.$: HLA-A*0206 and HLA-B*4403 are associated with cold-medicine-related SJS and TEN.

citation.$: Ueta M, Sawai H, Sotozono C, et al. IKZF1, a new susceptibility gene for cold medicine-related Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis with severe mucosal involvement. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2015;135:1538-1545.

para.$: HLA-A*3101 has a strong association with SJS and TEN ocular and other complications regardless of ethnicity.

citation.$: Yip VL, Alfirevic A, Pirmohamed M. Genetics of immune-mediated adverse drug reactions: a comprehensive and clinical review. Clin Rev Allergy Immunol. 2015;48:165-175.
